Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Agriculture (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Livestock and Foreign Agriculture
Title: Examination of Federal and State Response to Avian Influenza
Description: The House Committee on Agriculture Subcommittee on Livestock and Foreign Agriculture held a hearing on the recent large-scale outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza in the United States, which had spread through 21 states. The Subcommittee heard from Department of Agriculture officials in the and state officials. Conversation centered on lessons learned from the response to the outbreak, the adequacy of the agricultural industry's biosecurity plans and measures, and the development of a vaccine to combat the virus.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Agriculture (US)
Title: Review of the issues related to the prevention, detection, and eradication of avian influenza
Description: The House Committee on Agriculture held a hearing to review issues related to the prevention, detection, and eradication of avian influenza. Discussion addressed the importance of addressing the health of both humans and animals in order to safeguard against influenza outbreaks. The Administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service spoke to that agency's efforts to prevent, detect, and respond to an outbreak of avian influenza in poultry.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies
Title: Agriculture, Rural Development, and Related Agencies Appropriations: Hearing on Avian Influenza
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies held a hearing on the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) 2006 budget request. Among other topics, discussion considered the H5N1 avian influenza outbreaks happening around the world and the need for funding to address them. Members discussed how to adjust the USDA's budget for the next year in order to preserve surveillance efforts in light of the President's request for budget cuts.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs
Title: Avian Influenza--International Response
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs held a hearing on international responses to the global H5N1 avian influenza outbreaks. The Subcommittee explored whether U.S. and global efforts to understand, prevent, and control avian flu were successfully coordinated. Testimony addressed Fiscal Year 2006 expenditures and Fiscal Year 2007 budgetary requests.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Homeland Security
Title: Department of Homeland Security Appropriations for 2009
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security held a hearing to evaluate the Department of Homeland Security's Fiscal Year 2009 budget request. Members particularly focused on the Office of health Affairs, and its request for its BioWatch biodetection program, its efforts to integrate federal biosurveillance efforts, and its role in supporting the Department of Health and Human Services' BIoShield medical countermeasure acquisition program.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Homeland Security
Title: Biosurveillance: Smart Investments for Early Warning
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security held a hearing on the Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) biosurveillance activities. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior DHS officials and others. Conversation centered on BioWatch, an environmental detection program; the National Biosurveillance Integration Center; technological barriers and implementation challenges for both programs; and the value of early detection for a response to a biological event.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Department of Labor, HHS, Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations: Hearing on Pandemic Preparedness and Influenza Vaccine Supply
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing on pandemic preparedness. The hearing addressed issues such as public health system readiness and the available supply of influenza vaccines. Discussants considered the risk of avian influenza becoming a serious threat to public health and whether the U.S. public health system was prepared for such an eventuality.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies Appropriations for 2006
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing to examine the U.S. public health system's preparedness for a pandemic influenza. Discussion emphasized the emergence of H5N1 avian influenza, and addressed key elements of the Department of Health and Human Services' Pandemic Influenza Plan. Discussants highlighted the importance of strong surveillance systems as well as the creation of a national vaccine stockpile.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Appropriations: Hearing on Ebola Budget
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held an oversight hearing to examine the use of emergency funds requested by the Obama Administration to combat the spread of the West Africa Ebola epidemic. This compilation of statements from the hearing included statements from the Subcommittee Chairman and from the witnesses, who were senior officials with the Department of Health and Human Services. Topics discussed included the development of medical countermeasures to combat Ebola through the Public Health Emergency Medical Countermeasures Enterprise, the strengthening of medical capacity in the United States through the Hospital Preparedness Program, and the ongoing role of the United States in public health emergency response abroad and at home.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Health and Human Services Biodefense Activities
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held an oversight hearing to examine Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) activities to improve biodefense and public health emergency preparedness. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior HHS officials. Conversation centered on how HHS was spending current funds, whether its funding requests were adequate, how HHS could create sustainable programs to ensure preparedness, and how HHS was supporting medical countermeasure development, acquisition, and storage in the Strategic National Stockpile.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health, and Human Services, and Education
Title: Oversight Hearing—Public Health Emergency Medical Countermeasures Enterprise
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held an oversight hearing (see pages 1-118) to examine the activities of the Public Health Emergency Medical Countermeasure Enterprise (PHEMCE), a grouping of federal agencies involved in the development of medical countermeasures. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials in the Department of Health and Human Services. Conversation centered on the extent to which PHEMCE was adequately creating functional countermeasures, competition between funding for PHEMCE and other forms of public health preparedness, and the extent to which PHEMCE was focusing enough on emerging infectious disease threats from nature in addition to biological agents that might be used for bioterrorism.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs
Title: Funding to Prevent, Prepare for, and Respond to the Ebola Virus Disease Outbreak
Description: The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs held an oversight hearing (see pages 1-110) to investigate the use of emergency appropriations to support the U.S. government response to the West Africa Ebola epidemic. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials at the Department of State and U.S. Agency for International Development. Topics discussed included the actions taken by the U.S. government, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and other actors to combat the epidemic; ongoing steps necessary to contain the epidemic; and the importance of further support for preparedness abroad, including through the Global Health Security Agenda.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities
Title: Outside Views on Biodefense for the Department of Defense
Description: The House Committee on Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities held a hearing to investigate the findings of the Blue Ribbon Study Panel on Biodefense (later renamed the Bipartisan Commission on Biodefense), a privately-funded panel of former federal government officials that investigated U.S. biodefense posture. Two members of the Study Panel testified to the magnitude of the threat from biological events, including emerging infectious disease from nature, biological attacks, and biological accidents. Their recommendations included centralizing leadership for biodefense activity in the Office of the Vice President, establishing a national biodefense strategy, aligning fragmented programs across agencies, improving counter-biological weapons programs at the Department of Defense, and expanding congressional oversight of biodefense activity.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Intelligence, Emerging Threats and Capabilities
Title: Biodefense: Worldwide Threats and Countermeasure Efforts for the Department of Defense
Description: The House Committee on Armed Services Subcommittee on Intelligence, Emerging Threats and Capabilities held a hearing to evaluate biological weapons programs that might pose a threat to national security. Testimony was heard from private sector witnesses. The Subcommittee discussed biological weapons technology, medical countermeasures for pandemic influenza and other pathogens, and the overall ways in which strong biodefense systems can help protect against a bioweapons attack.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Military Procurement and the Subcommittee on Military Research
Title: U.S. Forces: Threat Posed By Proliferation of Chemical and Biological Weapons
Description: The House Committee on Armed Services Subcommittees on Military Procurement and on Military Research and Development held a joint hearing on the threat to U.S. forces posed by the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. The subcommittees heard updates on foreign biological and chemical weapons programs and the implications for U.S. defense. The DoD also presented its program for improving the U.S. forces' chemical and biological defenses, including personal protective equipment and medical countermeasures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Terrorism, Unconventional Threats and Capabilities
Title: Fiscal Year 2004 National Defense Authorization Act: Department of Defense efforts to address the chemical and biological threat
Description: The House Committee on Armed Services Subcommittee on Terrorism, Unconventional Threats and Capabilities held a hearing on Department of Defense policy and programs to counter the threat of weapons of mass destruction (WMD). Witnesses described advances in military technology to protect against a WMD threat. Among other topics, testimony described the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency's Unconventional Pathogen Countermeasures program, which works to develop medical countermeasures for naturally occurring and intentional biologic threats, moving beyond "one-bug-one-drug" therapties.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Jointly between Subcommittee on Health and Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Flu Vaccine: Protecting High-Risk Individuals and Strengthening the Market
Description: Two subcommittees of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, the Subcommittee on Health and the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, jointly held a hearing on the shortage of vaccines to address seasonal influenza. The subcommittees heard testimony from federal and outside witnesses. Conversation centered on the lack of suppliers for influenza vaccine, regulatory oversight of vaccine development, vaccine delivery planning, and opportunities for collaboration between the federal government and the private sector in the development of medical countermeasures for influenza.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Furthering Public Health Security: Project Bioshield
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health met jointly with the House Select Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness and Response to discuss the proposed federal medical countermeasures acquisition program, Project BioShield. The committees received testimony from the Secretary of Health and Human Services and private sector witnesses, hearing updates on bioterrorism preparedness and perspectives on how the acquisition program might work. Dr. Anthony Fauci, who was present, was asked to comment and noted that a lot of the expertise that has been built for biodefense to intentional acts could be applied to naturally occurring infections like severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) or pandemic influenza.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: The Threat of and Planning for Pandemic Flu
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health held a hearing on the threat of pandemic influenza. Members and witnesses discussed the nature of the threat, including links to animal influenzas, and  advances in influenza preparedness, such as vaccine availability. Some discussants expressed concern that the United States was under-prepared for an influenza pandemic.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Examining Medical Product Development in the Wake of the Ebola Epidemic
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health held a hearing to investigate barriers to the development of medical countermeasures to combat Ebola virus disease in response to the West Africa Ebola epidemic. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials with the Department of Health and Human Services. Topics discussed included the role of the federal government in catalyzing the development of countermeasures through the Public Health Emergency Medical Countermeasures Enterprise, insufficient financial incentives for proactive vaccine and therapeutic development, and the Food and Drug Administrations's  Priority Review Voucher program for neglected tropical diseases.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Examining H.R. 3299, Strengthening Public Health Response Act
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health held a legislative hearing on a proposed bill, H.R. 3299, the "Strengthening Public Health Response Act." The Act would modify the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act to further address incentivizes for the development of medical countermeasures, stockpiling in the Strategic National Stockpile, and elements of the Hospitals Preparedness Program to boost medical surge capacity for health emergencies. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials within the Department of Health and Human Services and Department of Defense.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Examining the Reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health held a hearing on issues relevant to the reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act (PAHPA). The Subcommittee heard from senior federal officials and individuals from outside the federal government. Conversation focused on the role of the federal government in directing preparedness, including by coordinating among localities, stockpiling medical countermeasures in the Strategic National Stockpile, conducting disease surveillance, protecting first responders, and addressing antimicrobial resistance.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Creating the Department of Homeland Security: Consideration of the Administration's Proposal - Part 1
Description: The Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations heard testimony about the creation of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a two-hearing series. Although the topics of the hearing were as wide-ranging as DHS' proposed mission spaces, it did cover infectious disease detection, medical preparedness, and related matters. The American Society for Microbiology, for instance, testified that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention should maintain authority for a variety of responsibilities related to response to public health threats like infectious disease outbreaks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Creating the Department of Homeland Security: Consideration of the Administration's Proposal - Part 2
Description: The Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations heard testimony about the creation of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a two-hearing series. Although the topics of the hearing were as wide-ranging as DHS' proposed mission spaces, it did cover infectious disease detection, medical preparedness, and related matters. The American Society for Microbiology, for instance, testified that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention should maintain authority for a variety of responsibilities related to response to public health threats like infectious disease outbreaks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: SARS: Assessment, Outlook, and Lessons Learned
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations heard updates on efforts to contain severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) cases in the United States, and evaluated future public health preparedness. Discussion noted that SARS control efforts had mainly been successful, but urged caution for influenza and other infectious disease pandemics. The Subcommittee noted particular weaknesses in detection capabilities and highlighted the importance of protecting the healthcare workforce

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Federal Oversight of High-Containment Biolaboratories
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on the federal government's oversight and regulation of high-containment laboratories, which handle pathogens associated with emerging infectious diseases. The Committee heard testimony from federal and other witnesses. Conversation centered on the findings of a Government Accountability Office report, which noted the recent proliferation of high-containment laboratories, the lack of an agency tasked with determine aggregate risk from these laboratories, and the resulting inability of the Federal Government to determine whether high-containment laboratory capacity met or exceeded the national need or was at a level that could be operated safely.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Influenza: Perspective on Current Season and Update on Preparedness
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to investigate the U.S. government's response to seasonal influenza, in light of the year's particularly severe flu season. The Subcommittee heard from senior officials in the Department of Health and Human Services and the Government Accountability Office. Conversation focused on activities to develop an effective vaccine, conduct disease surveillance, and increase vaccine uptake.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Examining the U.S. Public Health Response to the Ebola Outbreak
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to examine the United States' response to the 2014 Ebola outbreak. The Committee looked at the status of the outbreak and response efforts, considering clinical features of the disease, lack of vaccine availability, and risk to the United States. Discussion covered cases reported in Texas and mistakes that led to a slow response to the diagnosed Ebola case in Dallas.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Update on the U.S. Public Health Response to the Ebola Outbreak
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to provide updates on the U.S. public health response to the 2014 Ebola outbreak. The Subcommittee discussed lessons learned to date from the outbreak, and also focused on how a $6.2 billion emergency supplemental funding request would be spent for Ebola mitigation efforts.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Examining the U.S. Public Health Response to Seasonal Influenza
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to investigate the U.S. government's response to seasonal influenza, particularly in light of the year's low vaccine effectiveness. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials with the Department of Health and Human Services. Conversation centered on ways to improve vaccine effectiveness and generally improve medical countermeasure development, as well as other ways for the federal government to mitigate the spread of the virus.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: U.S. Public Health Preparedness for Seasonal Influenza: Has the Response Improved?
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on the U.S. government's actions to address seasonal influenza. The Subcommittee heard testimony from multiple senior officials within the Department of Health and Human Services. Topics discussed included the need for improved disease surveillance both within the United States and abroad, the importance of increasing vaccination rates and vaccine effectiveness, and improving vaccine manufacturing technologies.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Outbreaks, Attacks, and Accidents: Combatting Biological Threats
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on how to combat biological threats. The Subcommittee discussed the federal government's gaps in preparedness and recommendations for change. The Subcommittee considered outbreaks from intentional, natural, or accidental origins, hearing testimony from private sector witnesses on topics that included leadership, coordination, medical countermeasures, and hospital preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Examining the U.S. Public Health Response to the Zika Virus
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to examine U.S. response to the global outbreak of Zika virus disease. Testimony was heard from federal and non-federal witnesses who covered topics including surveillance, vaccines, and hospital readiness. The Subcommittee looked at medical, economic, and social effects of the outbreak, and discussed how previous outbreak responses tended to be reactionary.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Combatting Superbugs: U.S. Public Health Responses to Antibiotic Resistance
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on antimicrobial resistance (AMR). The Subcommittee heard testimony from officials within the Department of Health and Human Services largely on the topic of antibiotic resistance. Conversation covered the threat of antibiotic-resistant bacteria to hospital patients, collaboration among U.S. government agencies to combat AMR, and the development of new antibiotics and other treatments.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: U.S. Public Health Response to the Zika Virus: Continuing Challenges
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on the U.S. government's response to the spread of Zika virus within in the United States. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior federal government officials, including from the Department of Health and Human Services. The hearing touched on a report from the Government Accountability Office highlighting failures and challenges of the U.S. response—including the lack of a standardized case definition, difficulties in developing and approving effective diagnostics, and coordination issues between the federal and state governments—as well as efforts by U.S. agencies to combat the virus and the adequacy of funding levels thereof.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Examining U.S. Public Health Preparedness for and Response Efforts to Seasonal Influenza
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to examine the threat to the United States from seasonal influenza, with particular focus on the year's severe flu season and the nation's infrastructure to respond to this and other public health emergencies. The Subcommittee heard from senior officials within the Department of Health and Human Services. Among other topics, conversation centered on the role of flu vaccination (and other medical countermeasures), including issues with vaccine uptake, vulnerabilities of and timeliness issues with the egg-based vaccine manufacturing, and the potential for a universal flu vaccine.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: The State of U.S. Public Health Biopreparedness: Responding to Biological Attacks, Pandemics, and Emerging Infectious Disease Outbreaks
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on the state of U.S. preparedness for health emergencies. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior Department of Health and Human Services officials.  Conversation focused on the reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act; issues facing the Strategic National Stockpile in preparing an adequate supply of medical countermeasures; and the effort of U.S. government programs to better prepare for emerging infectious disease and pandemics, improve coordination, prevent and respond to biological attacks, and improve laboratory biosafety.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Title: Assessing the National Pandemic Flu Preparedness Plan
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce held a hearing to discuss the national pandemic influenza preparedness. The Secretary of Health and Human Services testified on the National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza and its implementation plan, and other actions taken by the Administration such as programs for global surveillance, cooperation with the international community, and development of an H5N1 influenza vaccine. The Committee explored how to increase vaccine manufacturing capacity by creating incentives for the adoption of new production technologies and provision of liability protections.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Energy and Commerce (US)
Title: Preparing for the 2009 Pandemic Flu
Description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce held a hearing on the nation's preparedness for the H1N1 influenza pandemic. The Committee heard testimony from senior officials within the Department of Health and Human Services. Conversation centered on the known features of the virus, the federal government's pandemic planning and response, the state of medical preparedness in hospitals and the broader health care system, the development of a vaccine, and the overlapping challenges posed by simultaneous waves of H1N1 and seasonal influenza.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Financial Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Pandemic Influenza Preparedness in the Financial Services Sector
Description: The House Committee on Financial Services Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing to evaluate the financial sector's preparedness for pandemic influenza. Members noted the leadership of the financial services sector in preparedness planning, and drew out challenges the sector was still facing. The hearing addressed the importance of telecommunications for maintaining continuity of operations, telecommuting strategies, and maintenance of financial data security.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health
Title: Global Health Emergencies Hit Home: The "Swine Flu" Outbreak
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health held a hearing on the pandemic spread of the H1N1 strain of influenza, with a focus on the virus' impacts on Africa and the United States. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials in the Department of Health and Human Services and the U.S. Agency for International Development. Conversation centered on the importance of funding for robust health system strengthening at home and abroad; surveillance issues with the pandemic, particularly in Africa; and the role of U.S. international aid for health.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations
Title: Combating the Ebola Threat
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations held a hearing to evaluate the 2014 Ebola outbreak. The subcommittee was interested in the risk the outbreak posed to the United States. Members also discussed potential assistance the United States could offer to West Africa to aid outbreak response.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations
Title: Global Efforts to Fight Ebola
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations held a hearing to reassess the ongoing 2014 Ebola outbreak. Federal and non-federal witnesses provided testimony on aspects of the outbreak response to date. The Subcommittee discussed the "critical mass" of medical resources needed to alleviate pressure in afflicted areas.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations
Title: Fighting Ebola: A Ground-Level View
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations held a hearing on implementation of international aid for the 2014 Ebola outbreak. The Subcommittee focused on actions taken in Liberia by non-governmental organizations. Scarcity of healthcare workers was discussed as a major barrier.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations
Title: Eradicating Ebola: Lessons Learned and Medical Advancements
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights, and International Organizations held a hearing on the ongoing outbreak of Ebola virus disease in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and the role of U.S. foreign assistance in addressing the outbreak. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Conversation focused on the difficulties of delivering aid and combatting the virus in a conflict zone, lessons learned from addressing the previous West Africa Ebola epidemic, and potential political barriers to delivering aid from the U.S. government to the DRC.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Terrorism, Nonproliferation and Trade
Title: National Strategy for Countering Biological Threats: Diplomacy and International Programs
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Terrorism, Nonproliferation and Trade held a hearing to evaluate the Obama Administration's National Strategy for Countering Biological Threats. The Subcommittee heard updates on diplomatic and international efforts to counteract bioterrorism, discussed the kinds of outbreaks that could have epidemic or pandemic potential, and considered the ways that the Strategy was structured to support both intentional and non-intentional outbreaks. The Subcommittee also discussed weaknesses in the strategy as identified by the Commission on the Prevention of Weapons of Mass Destruction Proliferation and Terrorism.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Title: Emerging Infectious Diseases: Threat to U.S.
Description: The House Committee on International Relations (now the Committee on Foreign Affairs) held a hearing on the threat emerging infectious diseases posed to national security. Members discussed the importance of international collaboration to create global monitoring networks as well as to provide global access to information. The Committee also examined U.S. contributions to international aid projects.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Title: Avian Flu: Addressing the Global Threat
Description: The House Committee on International Relations held a hearing on the threat of avian influenza. Discussion focused on how the increasingly interconnected world could influence outcomes of an avian influenza outbreak. Some discussants noted that international collaboration would be especially important in addressing a global threat like an emerging avian flu strain.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Foreign Affairs (US)
Title: Combating Ebola in West Africa: The International Response
Description: The House Committee on Foreign Affairs held a hearing on the role of the U.S. government and international actors in addressing the West Africa Ebola epidemic. The Committee heard testimony from several senior federal officials. Topics discussed included early failures of the World Health Organization (WHO) to respond adequately to the virus, the need for WHO reform, U.S. partnerships with other nations and with non-governmental organizations to combat the virus, and the economic impact of the epidemic.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence
Title: Counterterrorism Efforts to Combat a Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear (CBRN) Attack on the Homeland
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence held a hearing on counterterrorism efforts to prevent and respond to chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear attacks. The Subcommittee heard from federal officials and other experts. Among other topics, those present discussed: how an effective response capability was crucial to biodefense; the need for medical countermeasures against biological agents; the need for laboratory biosafety standards; and the need for assigned federal leadership for biodefense activity.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness and Response
Title: Disease Surveillance Systems
Description: The House Select Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness and Response held a hearing on that nation's disease surveillance/biosurveillance systems. The Subcommittee heard from federal witnesses and medical and scientific experts. Conversation touched on both environmental biodetection and surveillance of disease in humans, and largely centered on improving the biosurveillance systems' ability to detect a bioterrorist attack.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications
Title: Ensuring Effective Preparedness, Response, and Recovery for Events Impacting Health Security
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications held an oversight hearing on the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Health Affairs (OHA) efforts to prepare for and prevent biological events. The Subcommittee heard testimony from OHA leadership. The hearing focused on BioWatch, an OHA environmental detection system, as well as OHA's other activities, such as helping determine when border closures are recommended for slowing a disease outbreak.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications
Title: Taking Measure of Countermeasures (Part 1): A review of government and industry efforts to protect the homeland through accelerated research, development, and acquisition of chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear medical countermeasures
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications held a three-hearing series on medical countermeasures for outbreaks and other public health events. This hearing reviewed federal agencies' work on research, development, and procurement of medical countermeasures. The Subcommittee discussed barriers to progress, such as insufficient leveraging of the expertise and capabilities of larger, experienced biopharmaceutical companies due to the high opportunity costs of entering the limited chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear medical countermeasure market.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications
Title: Taking Measure of Countermeasures (Part 2): A Review of Efforts to Protect the Homeland Through Distribution and Dispensing of CBRN Medical Countermeasures
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications held a a three-hearing series on medical countermeasures for outbreaks and other public health events. This hearing reviewed federal agencies' efforts to develop plans for the distribution and dispensing of medical countermeasures in the case of a public health emergency. The Subcommittee discussed the value of public-private partnerships to increasing access to medical countermeasures via distribution and dispensing pathways, particularly in rural areas.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications
Title: Taking Measure of Countermeasures (Part 3): Protecting the Protectors
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications held a held a a three-hearing series on medical countermeasures for outbreaks and other public health events. This hearing addressed the needs of the response workforce. The Subcommittee was interested in how emergency response providers could be protected through vaccination and medical kit deployment in advance of an event, and other topics.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications
Title: Improving the Department of Homeland Security's Biological Detection and Surveillance Programs
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications held a hearing on Department of Homeland Security (DHS) biosurveillance programs, with a focus on their capability to detect a bioterrorist attack. The Committee heard from federal witnesses. Discussion centered on DHS programs including the National Biosurveillance Integration Center and BioWatch, and longstanding issues facing these programs as effective purveyors of critical biosurveillance information for situational awareness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications; and Subcommittee on Cybersecurity, Infrastructure Protection, and Security Technologies
Title: BioWatch Present and Future: Meeting Mission Needs for Effective Biosurveillance?
Description: Two subcommittees of the House Committee on Homeland Security jointly convened a hearing to examine the biosurveillance activities of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The subcommittees heard from experts within the federal government and from a state government official. Conversation focused on BioWatch, an environmental detection program, and discussions of whether the program and its planned expansion were advisable uses of resources to support effective biosurveillance and biodetection for infectious pathogens.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology
Title: Can BioShield Effectively Procure Medical Countermeasures that Safeguard the Nation?
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology held a hearing on Project Bioshield, a U.S. government program to fund the development of medical countermeasures against chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) threats. The Subcommittee heard testimony from individuals in the pharmaceutical sector as well as senior federal officials. Conversation centered on recent difficulties encountered by Project Bioshield and whether it could efficiently incentivize the development of medical countermeasures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology
Title: Beyond the Checklist: Addressing Shortfalls in National Pandemic Influenza Preparedness
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology held a hearing on planning for pandemic influenza. The subcommittee heard testimony from federal, state, and local officials. Conversation centered in the inadequacy of typical disease control measures during a severe pandemic, the rising threat of pandemic flu, the lack of coordination between the various levels of government and different agencies involved in pandemic preparedness, underfunding of public health, and gaps in the National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza and the National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza Implementation Plan.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology
Title: One Year Later: Implementing the Biosurveillance Requirements of the 9/11 Act
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology held a hearing to evaluate progress on implementation of the biosurveillance requirements of the 9/11 Act. Members particularly focused on the progress and future steps of the National Biosurveillance Integration Center and Project BioWatch. The Subcommittee urged further attention to threats of biological attacks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology
Title: Real-Time Assessment of the Federal Response to Pandemic Influenza
Description: The House Homeland Security Committee Subcommittee on Emerging Threats, Cybersecurity, and Science and Technology held an oversight hearing on the federal government's response to the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials in the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Homeland Security. Discussion focused on gaps in America's preparedness for pandemic influenza, including with respect to disease surveillance, government planning, medical capacity and delivery of health care under pandemic conditions, medical countermeasure and vaccine development, and the nation's public health infrastructure.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack
Title: Implementing the National Biodefense Strategy
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittee on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack held a hearing on implementation of the National Biodefense Strategy as framed by Homeland Security Presidential Directive 10 (HSPD-10), "Biodefense for the 21st Century." Federal witnesses testified to the pillars of biodefense as laid out in HSPD-10: threat awareness; prevention and protection; surveillance detection; and response and recovery. Conversation emphasized the need for interagency collaboration.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack
Title: Creating a Nationwide Integrated Biosurveillance Network
Description: The House Homeland Security Committee Subcommittee on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack held a hearing on the U.S. government's disease surveillance efforts in light of the possibility of the spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza. The Subcommittee heard from senior officials across the U.S. government. Conversation centered on the Department of Homeland Security's efforts to centralize all biosurveillance information from the U.S. government's various programs via a centralized National Biosurveillance Integration System (NBIS).

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack; Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Science and Technology
Title: Protecting the Homeland: Fighting Pandemic Flu From the Front Lines
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security Subcommittees on Prevention of Nuclear and Biological Attack and on Emergency Preparedness, Science, and Technology held a joint hearing to evaluate national preparedness for a pandemic influenza outbreak. Private sector witnesses discussed surveillance, medical countermeasures, and medical surge capacity, among other topics. The subcommittees considered efforts in the context of the national strategy for pandemic influenza.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Title: Towards A National Biodefense Strategy
Description: The House Select Committee on Homeland Security held a hearing on the development of national biodefense strategy. The hearing focused on progress in terms of the national medical stockpile, drug and vaccine development, and advances in detection technology. Discussion considered the need for investment to shorten the timeframe of medical countermeasures development.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Title: Are You Ready? Implementing the National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza
Description: The House Homeland Security Committee held a hearing to review the Homeland Security Council's "National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza Implementation Plan." The committee heard testimony from senior officials across the federal government. Conversation centered on the roles of different federal agencies and departments in mounting a response to pandemic influenza, when various non-pharmaceutical interventions should be implemented in the course of a pandemic, building medical surge capacity, and the need for coordination among governmental agencies and the private sector.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Homeland Security (US)
Title: Beyond Readiness: An Examination of the Current Status and Future Outlook of the National Response to Pandemic Influenza
Description: The House Committee on Homeland Security held a hearing to evaluate national response readiness for pandemic influenza. The Committee evaluated the Department of Homeland Security's response to H1N1 and determined what further action would need to be taken. Discussion emphasized the necessity of establishing clear leadership roles for future outbreak response.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security
Title: U.S. Biodefense, Preparedness, and Implications of Antimicrobial Resistance for National Security
Description: The Committee on Oversight and Reform Subcommittee on National Security held a hearing to examine whether the United States was prepared to respond to biological threats to national security. Federal and non-federal witnesses discussed both naturally occurring outbreaks and biological attacks. The Subcommittee also looked at the growing trend in antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and how it could affect national security.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security, Emerging Threats and International Relations
Title: Elusive Antidotes: Progress Developing Chemical, Biological, and Nuclear (CBRN) Countermeasures
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform Subcommittee on National Security, Emerging Threats, and International Relations held a hearing on medical countermeasures (MCM) for chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear (CBRN) threats. Discussion noted that the BioShield MCM acquisition program was insufficient alone to accelerate the biodefense pipeline. Members and witnesses considered the necessity of strong leadership, coordination, and adherence to a threat-based strategy in order to ensure preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security, Emerging Threats, and International Relations
Title: Anthrax Protection: Progress or Problems?
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform Subcommittee on National Security, Emerging Threats, and International Relations held hearing on the effectiveness of federal efforts to develop medical countermeasures (MCM) against anthrax, as well as the capability of the nation's biosurveillance system to detect an anthrax attack. The Subcommittee heard testimony from federal officials. Conversation centered on challenges to Project BioShield's development of MCM and challenges to establishing a broad surveillance capability, with some focus on difficulties of coordination between government agencies.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations
Title: DOD's Mandatory Anthrax Vaccine Immunization Program for Military Personnel
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations held a hearing to examine the U.S. Department of Defense's anthrax vaccine program. The hearing looked in particular at findings of a General Accounting Office report on the safety and efficacy of the vaccine for military personnel. Federal and non-federal witnesses testified and spoke to anthrax vaccine issues of relevance to medical preparedness in the military more generally.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations
Title: Anthrax Vaccine Adverse Reactions
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations held a hearing to examine anthrax vaccine adverse reactions. The Subcommittee invited federal and non-federal witnesses to explore evidence related to adverse events associated with vaccination of military personnel against anthrax. The hearing was an opportunity to examine force health protection for anthrax and the issues discussed were also relevant to medical preparedness for other biological threats.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations
Title: Chemical and Biological Defense: DoD Medical Readiness
Description: The House Committee Government Reform Subcommittee on National Security, Veterans Affairs, and International Relations held a hearing to examine the unique health threats posed by chemical and biological weapons. Witnesses from the Department of Defense addressed the General Accounting Office's recommendations for improvement in medical readiness. They also described contemporary and future planning to protect deployed forces from chemical and biological attacks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: The SARS Threat: Is the Nation's Public Health Network Prepared for a Possible Epidemic?
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform held a hearing on the public health system's response capabilities at the federal, state, and local levels. The Committee discussed whether the system was prepared for an emerging infectious disease based on the response to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Some of the discussion emphasized that current funding was insufficient and future investment in public health infrastructure would be needed.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: A Review of This Year's Flu Season: Does Our Public Health System Need a Shot in the Arm?
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform held a hearing on the nation's response to the latest year of seasonal influenza, using the season to examine the nation's preparedness for a pandemic of natural or intentional origins. The Committee heard testimony from federal, state, local, and non-governmental witnesses. Conversation centered on routes of collaboration between health agencies at the federal, state, and local levels; shortages of medical countermeasures (in this case, a shortage of flu vaccine); ensuring vaccine uptake; hospital preparedness; and ways to improve all of these efforts.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: The Next Flu Pandemic: Evaluating U.S. Readiness
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform held a hearing to evaluate U.S. ability to respond to the threat of a global influenza pandemic. Witnesses testified to federal government efforts and coordination among levels of government. Among other topics, discussion covered diagnostics for cases of avian influenza in poultry, vaccine preparedness, and medical surge capacity.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: The National Pandemic Influenza Preparedness and Response Plan: Is the U.S. Ready for Avian Flu?
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform held a hearing to examine the national plans for pandemic influenza preparedness and response. Members and witnesses discussed federal, state, and local preparedness for pandemic influenza, particularly in the context of an avian influenza they became transmissible to humans. Witnesses testified to gaps in the national strategy for pandemic influenza and suggested improvements.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: Working Through an Outbreak: Pandemic Flu Planning and Continuity of Operations
Description: The House Committee on Government Reform held a hearing on continuity of operations planning for a pandemic influenza outbreak. Discussion considered the national pandemic influenza strategy, with some noting that it provided insufficient support for state and local governments. Discussants noted that implementation of pandemic preparedness strategies was needed.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: FEMA Preparedness in 2007 and Beyond
Description: The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform held a hearing on Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) preparedness for disasters, including an influenza pandemic. The Committee heard testimony from witnesses from federal, state, and local governments and from others outside of government. Among many topics, conversation touched on FEMA's efforts to ensure medical surge capacity for disasters, and the likelihood that a disaster would put strain on an already strained health care system.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: State and Local Pandemic Preparedness
Description:
The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform held a hearing to evaluate state and local preparedness for pandemic influenza. The Committee received testimony from federal, state, local, and non-governmental witnesses. Members and witnesses discussed how communities could maintain an appropriate level of readiness to respond
to a pandemic influenza outbreak, and how federal authorities can assist them in counteracting local budget cuts. Much of the discussion put preparedness in the context of the H1N1 pandemic influenza outbreak.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Oversight and Reform (US)
Title: The Ebola Crisis: Coordination of a Multi-Agency Response
Description: The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform held a hearing to examine federal agency efforts to organize response to the West Africa Ebola outbreak. Conversation covered topics including ensuring healthcare worker safety, medical countermeasures, and hospital readiness. The Committee discussed how domestic actions during this outbreak may have damaged public trust in federal capabilities.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology (US)
Title: Fighting Flu, Saving Lives: Vaccine Science and Innovation
Description: The House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology held a hearing on advances in vaccine science, using influenza as a case study. The Committee discussed technology and data platforms that could accelerate vaccine development and improve vaccine efficacy. The Committee also discussed how to communicate vaccine safety to the public and to advance partnerships for vaccine deployment.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Small Business (US)
Title: The Challenges of the 2009: H1N1 Influenza and its Potential Impact on Small Businesses and Healthcare Providers
Description: The House Committee on Small Business held a hearing to evaluate the impact of the 2009 H1N1 influenza outbreak on small businesses. Testimony was heard from federal and private witnesses who explored the unique challenges small businesses faced during the pandemic and how the federal government could alleviate economic pressures. One witness raised the question of whether business closure decisions would be the decision of federal, state, or local governments, or the businesses themselves.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Aviation
Title: Efforts to Prevent Pandemics by Air Travel
Description: The House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure Subcommittee on Aviation held a hearing on air travel pandemic preparedness. Testimony was heard from federal and non-federal witnesses. Among other topics, discussion addressed the value in surveilling the traveling population for infectious disease, international reporting of detected outbreaks, and development of advanced detection technologies for individual aircraft.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight, Investigations, and Emergency Management
Title: Preparedness Against Terrorist Attacks
Description: The House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure Subcommittee on Oversight, Investigations and Emergency Management held a hearing on preparedness against terrorist attacks. The hearing covered medical preparedness elements like the Metropolitan Medical Response System, National Medical Response Teams, military medical reserve components, and medical countermeasures. Federal and non-federal witnesses provided testimony.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Veterans' Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Ten Years After: Lessons from the Gulf War
Description: The Subcommittee on Health held a hearing on operational and medical readiness in the Active Duty Forces. The subcommittee discussed the chemical and biological health risks many veterans experienced due to the Gulf War, and the fact that many forces experiencing problems suffered from a bacterial infection. Members discussed failures in Gulf War policy and necessary improvements to protect future generations.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Veterans' Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Health
Title: Military Medical Surveillance System Challenges
Description: The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health held a hearing to consider issues of operational and medical readiness in the active duty forces and their relationships to the health status of the veteran population. Key witnesses from the Department of Defense (DoD) and General Accounting Office (GAO) testified to DoD policies and evaluated opportunities for improvement. Some of the testimony addressed the DoD's engagement in overseas infectious disease surveillance such as through the Global Emerging Infections Surveillance program.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Veterans' Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations
Title: Department of Veterans Affairs' Flu Vaccination Program
Description: The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations held a hearing on the Department of Veterans Affairs' (VA) influenza vaccination program. The Subcommittee sought information about VA preparations for a possible avian influenza pandemic in people. Members raised concerns about a lack of interagency collaboration between the VA and the Departments of Defense, Health and Human Services, and Homeland Security.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): House Committee on Veterans' Affairs (US)
Title: Three Years After 9/11: Is VA Prepared to Fulfill Its Roles in Homeland Security?
Description: The House Committee on Veteran's Affairs held a hearing on the Department of Veterans' Affairs (VA) medical preparedness for a chemical, radiological, biological, or nuclear (CRBN) attack. The Committee received testimony on VA readiness to respond a a biological attack, and made analogies to what would be needed in the event of an outbreak of pandemic influenza on the scale of the 1918 outbreak, or severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Members discussed how Congress can help ensure that resources flow to the VA to enable it to protect its constituents from biological and other threats.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry (US)
Title: The role of United States Agriculture in the Control and Eradication of Avian Influenza
Description: The Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry held a hearing to examine the role of the U.S. agriculture community in the control and eradication of avian influenza. Members additionally discussed the human healthcare system's preparedness, availability of antiviral drugs, and potential enhancement of quarantine stations.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry (US)
Title: To Review the United States Department of Agriculture National Response Plan to Detect and Control the Potential Spread of Avian Influenza Into the United States
Description: The Senate Committee on Agriculture held a hearing to review the U.S. Department of Agriculture's plan to detect and stop the spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza among poultry in the United States. The committee heard testimony from the administrator of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. Topics discussed included the planned role of the USDA, as well as that of state and local agencies and the private sector.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry (US)
Title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza: The Impact on the U.S. Poultry Sector and Protecting U.S. Poultry Flocks
Description: The Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry held a hearing to discuss the U.S. poultry outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). The committee heard from officials within the Department of Agriculture (USDA) and individuals from the agricultural industry. Topics discussed included the magnitude of the threat to U.S. poultry, the response of the U.S. government and agricultural industry to the outbreak, and areas of potential improvement in responding to this and future HPAI outbreaks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry (US)
Title: Safeguarding American Agriculture in a Globalized World
Description: The Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry held a hearing to examine threats to American agriculture from pathogens and other biological events, including highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). The Committee heard testimony from multiple experts outside of the federal government. Conversation touched on the magnitude of biological threats to agriculture, fruitful areas for investment of federal resources, and the importance of coordination among levels of U.S. government to address those threats.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Ebola Outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Other Emerging Health Threats
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing to examine funding needs to address the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and other emerging health threats. The Subcommittee heard testimony from senior government officials on steps being taken to improve preparedness for health emergencies domestically and abroad. The conversation touched on funding for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the U.S. Agency for International Development, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Public Health Emergency Preparedness program grants to states, the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority, and the implementation of the Global Health Security Agenda.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Homeland Security
Title: Biodefense and Pandemic Influenza
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Homeland Security held a hearing on the U.S. government's efforts to prepare for pandemic influenza and biological attacks. The committee heard from multiple experts from outside the federal government. Discussion centered on ways the U.S. could improve preparedness, including by clearly establishing which organizations and officials will lead a health emergency response, improving disease surveillance activities, and streamlining the development of medical countermeasures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education
Title: First Special Hearing on Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies held a series of four hearings to assess ways to improve preparedness for and prevention of biological attacks, following the recent anthrax attacks. In this, the first hearing (see pages 1-92), the Subcommittee heard testimony from senators, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and experts outside of the federal government including state and local health officials. The Subcommittee discussed the need for investment in public health preparedness at all levels of government, including for improved disease surveillance, laboratory systems, medical surge capacity, development of medical countermeasures, and storage and deployment of countermeasures from the National Pharmaceutical Stockpile (later renamed the Strategic National Stockpile).

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Preparedness for Epidemics and Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing to examine the public health response to disease outbreaks caused by biological and chemical terrorism. The Subcommittee focused on the system of public health surveillance and control at federal, state, and local levels. Members also discussed certain terrorist incidents involving biological agents.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Second Special Hearing on Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a series of four hearings to assess ways to improve preparedness for and prevention of biological attacks, following the recent anthrax attacks. In this, the second hearing (see pages 93-154), the Subcommittee heard testimony from experts from within and outside of the federal government. The Subcommittee discussed appropriate levels of funding for various aspects of preparedness, including funding for public health agencies, improved hospital surge capacity, more thorough disease surveillance, and acquisition of medical countermeasures, including the smallpox vaccine.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Third Special Hearing on Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a series of four hearings to assess ways to improve preparedness for and prevention of biological attacks, following the recent anthrax attacks. In this, the third hearing (which focused specifically on smallpox; see pages 155-200), the Subcommittee heard testimony from senior Department of Health and Human services officials and individuals from outside of the federal government. Discussion centered on the magnitude of the threat of a smallpox attack, the value of vaccination to prevent smallpox, the feasible routes toward building a smallpox vaccine stockpile, and the value of public health investment to improve public health preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Fourth Special Hearing on Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a series of four hearings to assess ways to improve preparedness for and prevention of biological attacks, following the recent anthrax attacks. In this, the fourth hearing (see pages 201-255), the Subcommittee heard testimony from senior Department of Health and Human services officials and individuals from outside the federal government. Those present discussed the optimal funding levels for building up public health emergency preparedness, including for general strengthening of public health agencies, increasing lab capacity, improving disease surveillance, and accelerating the development of medical countermeasures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Global HIV/AIDS and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)
