Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education held a special hearing to examine the global AIDS crisis and the recent emergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). With respect to SARS, witnesses presented strategies the United States had taken to mitigate spread of SARS, focusing on travel restrictions and screenings.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations for 2005
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing on influenza vaccine. The Subcommittee discussed a proposed appropriations bill amendment that would have prohibited prevented the use of funds to purchase any flu vaccine containing thimerosal for children and its potential impacts on flu rates. The Subcommittee focused extensively on the safety of the vaccine.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Funding Needs for Pandemic Influenza Preparedness
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a special hearing to examine funding needs for pandemic influenza preparedness pursuant to the President's request for appropriations for avian influenza preparedness. Discussion focused on disease surveillance, vaccines, antivirals, public health infrastructure, and risk communication.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Pandemic Influenza Preparedness
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing to examine pandemic influenza preparedness at federal, state and local levels. Witnesses included experts from across governmental levels, the private sector, and academia. Discussion looked at preparedness efforts and paid special attention to the ongoing H5N1 avian influenza outbreak in Turkey and what it might mean for the United States.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Pandemic Influenza: Progress Made and Challenges Ahead
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies held a hearing on pandemic influenza, focusing on progress toward and barriers to developing medical countermeasures—especially vaccines, antiviral therapies, and diagnostics. The subcommittee heard testimony from senior officials in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and an outside medical expert. Conversation centered on funding needs and barriers to consistent funding for public health (including at the Center for Disease Control and Prevention); the most promising technologies for flu vaccine manufacturing (including cell-based and egg-based manufacturing); and how the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act altered the federal government's approach to the development of medical countermeasures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US)
Title: U.S. Government Response: Fighting Ebola and Protecting America
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations held a hearing to evaluate the U.S. government's actions to contain the West Africa Ebola epidemic, limit case importation to the United States, and address and treat cases in the United States. The Committee heard testimony from senior officials across the U.S. government and considered the Obama Administration's emergency Ebola funding request. Conversation centered on necessary response activities in West Africa, the roles of various U.S. agencies and the U.S. military in collaboration with other organizations to conduct the response abroad, screening for cases at American ports of entry, the development and regulation of medical countermeasures, and hospital preparedness in the United States.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US),Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies
Title: Ebola in West Africa: A Global Challenge and Public Health Threat
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions and the Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education and Related Agencies jointly held a hearing on the growing West Africa Ebola epidemic and the funding needs of the U.S. government to help address it. The committees heard testimony from senior officials within the Department of Health and Human Services and individuals from the nonprofit sector. Conversation focused on the nature of the epidemic, the threat it posed in West Africa and to U.S. citizens, the need for health system strengthening around the world, and the development of medical countermeasures to combat Ebola.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Appropriations (US),Senate Committee on Veterans’ Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies
Title: Bioterrorism - Domestic Weapons of Mass Destruction
Description: The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Related Agencies and the Committee on Veteran's Affairs held a joint hearing on the roles and preparedness of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Veterans Affairs to respond to a domestic chemical or biological weapons attack. The committees also discussed how to partner federal investments with existing grassroots public health organizations and infrastructure to improve medical response.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats
Title: The Dark Winter Scenario and Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats held hearings, in closed and open session, to examine the Dark Winter scenario designed to assess the national security, intergovernmental, and information challenges of a biologic attack on the American homeland. Members discussed how to improve public health and medical infrastructure so that it was on the same level as research in the country.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Armed Services (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities
Title: Biological Threats to United States National Security
Description: The Senate Committee on Armed Services Subcommittee on Emerging Threats and Capabilities held a hearing in response to the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Commission on Strengthening Health Security report, "Ending the Cycle of Crisis and Complacency in U.S. Global Health Security." The committee received testimony on the magnitude of the threat of biological events (including emerging infectious disease, intentional biological attacks, and biological accidents) to the United States. The hearing also focused on U.S. efforts to mitigate that threat through implementing the 2018 National Biodefense Strategy, stockpiling medical countermeasures in the Strategic National Stockpile, innovation in biotechnology, and the activities of Department of Defense.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Armed Services (US)
Title: Department of Defense Anthrax Vaccine Immunization Program - Part 1
Description: The Senate Committee on Armed Services convened a two-hearing series on the U.S. Department of Defense anthrax vaccine immunization program. Federal witnesses were invited to testify to the controversial program to vaccinate service members as part of a medical preparedness effort for potential anthrax exposure. Conversation emphasized the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and the validity of the perceived threat.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Armed Services (US)
Title: Department of Defense Anthrax Vaccine Immunization Program - Part 2
Description: The Senate Committee on Armed Services convened a two-hearing series on the U.S. Department of Defense anthrax vaccine immunization program. Federal witnesses were invited to testify to the controversial program to vaccinate service members as part of a medical preparedness effort for potential anthrax exposure. Conversation emphasized the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and the validity of the perceived threat.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Trade, Tourism, and Economic Development
Title: The State of the U.S. Travel and Tourism Industry
Description: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation Subcommittee on Trade, Tourism, and Economic Development held a hearing on challenges facing the air travel and tourism industries, with one focus being the challenges posed by pandemic disease such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The subcommittee heard testimony from officials across the federal government and industry representatives. Topics discussed included the U.S. government's implementation of travel restrictions to combat pandemic disease and the threat of pandemic influenza to airlines, the travel industry, and the broader economy.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources (US)
Title: Homeland Security
Description: The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources held a hearing to evaluate the past and present contributions of the national laboratories of the Department of Energy and National Nuclear Security Administration in protecting U.S. homeland security. The hearing explored how the new Department of Homeland Security might affect ongoing research programs, touching on issues including biosurveillance, environmental monitoring, and medical countermeasures. The Committee concluded that the Bush Administration should draw on existing capabilities in national laboratories, industry, and universities in order to promote homeland security.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Foreign Relations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health Policy
Title: A Progress Report on the West Africa Ebola Epidemic
Description: The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health Policy held a hearing to examine the international response to the West Africa Ebola epidemic, which was subsiding at the time of the hearing. The subcommittee heard testimony from leaders from non-governmental organizations and the private sector. Conversation focused on the successes and failures of the United States and other actors in responding to the pandemic, as well as the ideal U.S. role of in health system strengthening and public health emergency response abroad.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Foreign Relations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health Policy
Title: Confronting Ebola: Addressing a 21st Century Global Health Crisis
Description: The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Africa and Global Health Policy held a hearing on the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The Committee heard testimony from U.S. government officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Department of State, and U.S. Agency for International Development. The hearing focused on how the United States could work with partners (including the World Health Organization) to address the epidemic in a conflict-affected area, and the value of international aid for addressing and preventing health emergencies.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Foreign Relations (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on African Affairs
Title: The Ebola Epidemic: The Keys to Success for the International Response
Description: The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Subcommittee on African Affairs held a hearing on the international response to the West Africa Ebola epidemic, including the role of the U.S. government. The subcommittee heard testimony from the president of Liberia and individuals from non-governmental organizations. Conversation centered on U.S. actions in fighting the epidemic, the role of U.S. collaboration with non-governmental organizations and other states, and the value of investing in health system strengthening and public health emergency preparedness in sub-Saharan Africa.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Foreign Relations (US)
Title: Avian Influenza: Are We Prepared?
Description: The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations held a hearing to examine the need for a response strategy to address the threat of H5N1 avian influenza. Discussion focused on measures to stop the spread of the virus in Asia and to prevent a pandemic. Members also considered how to respond to H5N1 if it did enter the United States.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: Biodefense: Next Steps
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing to examine next steps in biodefense, addressing such programs as the National Institute of Health's biodefense research portfolio and the Department of Health and Human Services' medical countermeasure acquisition program, Project BioShield. The hearing reviewed advancements in the the development of medical countermeasures for a bioterrorist attack. Discussion also emphasized a perceived lack of preparedness for naturally occurring diseases.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: Twenty-First Century Biological Threats
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing on contemporary and emerging bioterrorism threats. The Subcommittee emphasized the need for a biodefense system that worked well against both deliberate, accidental, and natural biological threats.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: Crossing the Valley of Death: Bringing Promising Medical Countermeasures to BioShield
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing to examine promising medical countermeasures. Discussed considered the Project BioShield Act of 2004. It also addressed the Administration's priority to have an appropriate armamentarium of medical countermeasures as a critical aspect of the response and recovery component of the President's "Biodefense for the 21st Century" strategy.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: Roundtable Discussion: When Terror Strikes - Preparing an Effective and Immediate Public Health Response
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing to discuss preparing an effective and immediate public health response in the aftermath of a terrorism attack. They discussed the lack of a supply store in the event that a medical and public health surge on supplies was needed. Others expressed concerns about how reliance on vaccines may not prove useful in the event of an emerging disease. (Following the release of the initial hearing report, the Government Printing Office released an addendum containing additional hearing materials. These materials have been appended to the PDF available here.)

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: Roundtable Discussion: Preparing a National Biodefense: S. 975
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing examining S. 975, a bill designed to provide incentives to increase private sector research to develop medical countermeasures to prevent, detect, identify, contain, and treat illnesses for chemical, biological, radiological, or nuclear weapons attacks or other infectious disease outbreaks. Subcommittee Members urged further investment into public health infrastructure.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness
Title: All-Hazards Medical Preparedness and Response
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Bioterrorism and Public Health Preparedness held a hearing to examine all-hazards emergency response capabilities. Members continued their discussion of the reauthorization of the Public Health, Security, and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002. Among other topics, hearing discussion emphasized how federal agencies could support state and local preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Public Health
Title: Examining the Public Health Problem of Antimicrobial Resistance, or the Ability of Bacteria to Become Resistant to Antibiotics
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Public Health examined the problem of antimicrobial resistance. Federal and private witnesses spoke to various aspects of the antimicrobial resistance problem and the global threat it posed. The issue was described by some witnesses as an epidemic and a pending pandemic that required attention.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Public Health
Title: Bioterrorism: Our Frontline Response, Evaluating US Public Health and Medical Readiness
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Public Health held a hearing on bioterrorism defense, focusing on public health and medical readiness. Members examined the unique challenges a bioterrorist attack would pose and discussed strategies on outbreak containment and investigation. The Subcommittee also heard updates on the national pharmaceutical stockpile and on research and development.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Public Health
Title: Effective Responses to the Threat of Bioterrorism
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee on Public Health held a hearing to examine response to bioterrorist threats such as infectious diseases. They focused on detection, treatment, and containment measures, and addressed how to improve response in each category. The Subcommittee also reflected on recent innovations and policy advances in bioterrorism preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Homeland Security
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing on the President's proposal to create a Department of Homeland Security (DHS), focusing on the effect this would have on public health preparedness programs in the federal government. The Committee heard from a federal witness. Conversation centered on various concerns about the proposed relocation of programs focused on medical countermeasure development, hospital preparedness, and public health emergency preparedness from the Department of Health and Human Services to DHS.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Threat
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing to examine the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) threat. The hearing focused on vaccine development, drug screening, and clinical research. Witnesses testified to U.S. capabilities to respond to the SARS outbreak.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing to examine the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) threat. Members assessed knowledge about the disease and reflected on U.S. medical preparedness for SARS. The Committee considered effective methods of prevention and mitigation, focusing on Canada's response to contain SARS.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Federal Biodefense Readiness
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing to examine federal biodefense readiness, focusing on the public health workforce. Members heard updates on the status of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention terrorism preparedness and emergency response activities, as well as the Emergency Communication System. The Committee also discussed smallpox preparedness, the Food and Drug Administration's role in counterterrorism activities, vulnerability and threat assessments, laboratory enhancements, research, Operation Liberty Shield, and development of the research infrastructure.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Enhancing Public Health and Medical Preparedness: Reauthorization of the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing to discuss the proposed reauthorization of Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act. Members evaluated the effectiveness of government programs, focusing on how they had helped prepare for influenza and bioterrorism.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Facing 21st Century Public Health Threats: Our Nation’s Preparedness and Response Capabilities, Part I
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing on U.S. efforts to prepare for pandemics and other biological events, as the first in a series of two hearings. The Committee heard testimony from multiple officials from the Department of Health and Human Services. Discussion focused on the reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act, U.S. investments in medical countermeasures and hospital preparedness, and U.S. assistance abroad to improve public health emergency preparedness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (US)
Title: Facing 21st Century Public Health Threats: Our Nation’s Preparedness and Response Capabilities, Part 2
Description: The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions held a hearing on U.S. efforts to prepare for pandemics and other biological events, the second in two-hearing series. The Committee heard testimony from a variety of experts and health practitioners outside of the federal government. Discussion focused on the reauthorization of the Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness Act; funding for hospitals; support for state and local health departments and public health surveillance; and the role of an all-hazards approach that addresses the delivery of health care during disaster situations.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Ad Hoc Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration
Title: Pandemic Influenza: State and Local Efforts to Prepare
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Ad Hoc Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration held a hearing on efforts by states and localities to prepare for pandemic influenza. The Subcommittee heard testimony from officials from the federal, state, and local governments. Conversation centered on the broad variety of federal departments and agencies involved in pandemic preparedness; constraints on local decision-makers who might need to act quickly with limited information, resources, and experience; and the value of partnerships between different levels of government.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Ad Hoc Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration
Title: Pandemic Flu: Closing the Gaps
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Ad Hoc Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration held a hearing on pandemic preparedness, with a focus on state and local health departments in the context of the H1N1 influenza pandemic. The Subcommittee heard testimony from  the Government Accountability Office as well as multiple individuals outside of the federal government with expertise in state governments and state health departments. Conversation centered on actions that the federal government could take to improve preparedness, as well as ways to improve coordination between levels of government and the private sector.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Jointly between full committee and Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation and Federal Services
Title: Federal Efforts to Coordinate and Prepare the United States for Bioterrorism: Are They Ready?
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs held a joint hearing with its own Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation and Federal Services on federal efforts to coordinate and prepare the United States for bioterrorism. The hearing, held in the weeks that the Amerithrax anthrax attacks were unfolding, examined how well governments at all levels from local to federal were prepared to respond to a biological or chemical attack. Discussion from federal and non-federal witnesses examined topics relating to medical preparedness for biological incidents, including medical countermeasures, response surge capacity, and hospital readiness.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Jointly between full committee and Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation and Federal Services
Title: Terrorism Through the Mail: Protecting Postal Workers and the Public
Description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs held a joint hearing with its Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation and Federal Services to examine the effects of terrorism on the U.S. mail service, focusing on safeguards to protect postal employees and its customers. Key witnesses testified to how the Postal Service and public health officials had responded to recent anthrax attacks, issues of biosurveillance (including environmental biodetection and public health surveillance), and medical response to the attacks (including distribution of medical countermeasures).

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations
Title: SARS: State and Local Response
Description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations held hearings to examine severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), focusing on state and local response. The Subommittee discussed how to improve coordination of response to individual outbreaks among federal, state, and local officials, as well as between government officials and the private sector. Members also considered what state and local officials were doing to anticipate and respond to the disease.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations
Title: SARS: Best Practices for Identifying and Caring for New Cases
Description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations held a hearing to examine best practices for identifying and caring for new cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Members considered control measures to help contain the spread of SARS should future outbreaks occur. Hearing discussion emphasized that emergency response at the local level was inadequate and required more attention.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia
Title: The Role of Federal Executive Boards in Pandemic Preparedness
Description: As the first hearing in a three-part series on pandemic influenza, the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia held a hearing on the role of federal executive boards (FEBs) in combating pandemic influenza. The Subcommittee heard testimony from federal government and FEB officials. Conversation centered on the role of FEBs in ensuring continuity of operations for the federal workforce during an influenza pandemic and their potential to serve a broader role in the federal government's emergency planning, including for health emergencies.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia
Title: Preparing the National Capital Region for a Pandemic
Description: As the second hearing in a three-part series on pandemic influenza, the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia held a hearing on preparedness for pandemic influenza in the National Capital Region (NCR). The subcommittee heard testimony from officials in the federal government and local NCR government agencies. Discussion centered on the role of strategic plans for pandemic influenza, federal funding, and coordination/communication between agencies and jurisdictions to improve continuity of operations, medical surge capacity, and public communications during an influenza pandemic.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia
Title: Forestalling the Coming Pandemic: Overseas Infectious Disease Surveillance
Description: As the third hearing in a three-part series on pandemic influenza, the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia held a hearing to evaluate infectious disease surveillance/biosurveillance systems abroad. The subcommittee heard testimony from officials across the federal government and experts outside of government. Discussion centered on whether existing systems provided U.S. policymakers with adequate information on emerging outbreaks, the importance of early detection of emerging infectious diseases to contain outbreaks, and information gaps and areas for further expansion of disease surveillance activity.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia
Title: Protecting Our Employees: Pandemic Influenza Preparedness and the Federal Workforce
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management, the Federal Workforce, and the District of Columbia held a hearing on the federal government's continuity of operations planning in the content of the H1N1 influenza pandemic. The Subcommittee heard testimony from federal officials and representatives of unions for federal employees. The conversation focused on gaps in agencies' pandemic workforce plans and opportunities to improve this planning, such as through incorporating the use of telework/telecommuting/work-from-home.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration
Title: A Review of Disaster Medical Preparedness: Improving Coordination and Collaboration in the Delivery of Medical Assistance During Disasters
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Ad Hoc Subcommittee on State, Local, and Private Sector Preparedness and Integration held a hearing on medical capacity and medical preparedness for health emergencies. The Committee heard testimony from federal officials and a representative from a hospital association on preparedness for pandemics and other disasters. Topics discussed included the National Disaster Medical System and governmental coordination involved in a medical response to an emergency,

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: FEMA's Role in Managing Bioterrorist Attacks and the Impact of Public Health Concerns on Bioterrorism Preparedness
Description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation and Federal Services held a hearing to examine the role of the Federal Emergency Management Agency in managing a bioterrorist attack. They identified surveillance, quick and decisive investigation into an incident, and appropriate emergency response as the three main pillars of bioterrorism preparedness. The Subcommittee also analyzed whether lessons from simulations such as TOPOFF and Dark Winter were being applied to public health policy.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Public Health Preparedness for Terrorism Involving Weapons of Mass Destruction
Description: The Senate Committee on Government Affairs  held hearings to examine the state of public health preparedness for terrorism involving weapons of mass destruction. Members analyzed federal efforts to coordinate and communicate with public health and law enforcement agencies in the event of a terrorist attack with public health implications, such as an infectious disease outbreak, and certain budgetary requirements to implement homeland security measures.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Preparing for Reality: Protecting Against Weapons of Mass Destruction
Description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs looked at ways to protect against weapons of mass destruction, including biological attacks. Although terrorism was the focus, discussion addressed commonalities with naturally occurring epidemics, and the need to ensure that both law enforcement and public health officials are empowered to respond. One witness noted that meaningful progress against the biological threat depends on understanding it in the context of infectious and/or epidemic disease.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Six Years After Anthrax: Are We Better Prepared to Respond to Bioterrorism?
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs held a hearing on advances in U.S. preparedness for bioterrorist attacks in the years since the 2001 anthrax attacks, with discussion many aspects of preparedness also applicable to natural outbreaks of emerging infectious disease. The Committee heard from federal officials and an outside witness. Topics of discussion included medical countermeasure development and challenges to that endeavor, particularly for Project BioShield; gaps in disease surveillance and environmental biodetection programs, including BioWatch; and medical surge capacity needed in a health emergency.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Ten Years After 9/11 and the Anthrax Attacks: Protecting Against Biological Threats
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs held a hearing (pp. 281-322 and 1144-1223) to examine the federal government's biodefense activity ten years after the 9/11 attacks and the 2001 anthrax attacks. The Committee heard from experts within and outside the federal government. Conversation centered on the federal government's response capabilities for biological attacks and emerging infectious disease, with a focus on biosurveillance/disease surveillance, hospital preparedness, medical countermeasure development and distribution, coordination among the myriad agencies and levels of government involved in biodefense activity, and laboratory biosafety.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Preparedness and Response to Public Health Threats: How Ready Are we?
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs held a hearing to investigate U.S. preparedness for global health emergencies broadly and specifically its response to the West Africa Ebola epidemic. Members and witnesses discussed the Obama Administration's approximately $6.2 billion emergency appropriations request to combat the virus. Discussion focused on the known qualities of the disease and elements of preparedness in the United States, including governmental coordination, infection control measures (such as traveler screenings), development of medical countermeasures through the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority, and leadership from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Stopping an Avian Influenza Threat to Animal and Public Health
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs held a hearing to examine the U.S. poultry outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). The Committee heard from witnesses across the federal government as well as outside of government. Conversation focused on the threat of HPAI to birds and to humans, the U.S. government and agricultural industry's response to the outbreak, and ways to improve preparedness for future outbreaks.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: Assessing the State of Our Nation's Biodefense
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (HSGAC) held a hearing to examine the findings of the Blue Ribbon Study Panel on Biodefense, as put forward in the Panel's report, "A National Blueprint for Biodefense." The Committee heard testimony from the Study Panel co-chairs, and followed this hearing with another on April 14, 2016, in which HSGAC heard from federal officials. Conversation at this hearing centered on the ongoing threat of biological events (including emerging infectious disease from nature, biological attacks, and biological accidents) to the United States; ongoing gaps in U.S. preparedness; and the Panel's recommendations to remedy those gaps, which included establishing senior federal political leadership for biodefense and coordinating biodefense activity and budgeting across the many agencies tasked with biodefense-related programs.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (US)
Title: The Federal Perspective on the State of Our Nation's Biodefense
Description: The Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs (HSGAC) held a hearing on the adequacy of biodefense activities across the federal government, in part as a follow up to an October 28, 2015 hearing in which HSGAC examined the recommendations and findings of the Blue Ribbon Study Panel on Biodefense's report, "A National Blueprint for Biodefense." The Committee heard testimony from various senior federal officials. Conversation centered on steps being taken to improve coordination of biodefense activity across the federal government and the degree to which the Study Panel's recommendations should be implemented.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on the Judiciary (US)
Subcommittee(s) (name at time of hearing: Subcommittee on Terrorism and Homeland Security
Title: Strengthening Security and Oversight at Biological Research Laboratories
Description: The Senate Committee on the Judiciary Subcommittee on Terrorism and Homeland Security held a hearing on high-containment laboratory security and oversight in the United States. The Subcommittee heard testimony from federal and non-federal witnesses. High-containment biological laboratories host research on dangerous infectious pathogens, which may be deliberately or accidentally released and cause outbreaks; hearing discussion focused on the federal government's efforts to improve security and oversight and recommendations from outside experts on how to do so.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs (US)
Title: Lessons Learned from Desert Storm Regarding Chemical and Biological Weapons Preparedness
Description: The Senate Committee on Veteran's Affairs held a hearing to examine the medical, chemical, and biological warfare preparedness program of the Department of Defense (DoD), focusing on lessons learned from Persian Gulf War illnesses. The Committee examined various events from operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm and determined gaps in the DoD's strategy to protect its troops from chemical and biological agents, which include infectious pathogens. They also highlighted updates in countermeasures research that could improve protections.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Special Committee on Aging (US)
Title: The Vaccine Vacuum: What Can Be Done to Protect Seniors?
Description: The Senate Special Committee on Aging held a hearing to examine how vaccine availability for seniors could be ensured. Discussion addressed influenza vaccine and the shortages that had occurred during the prior autumn. One witnesses noted that a future pandemic influenza must be planned for with respect to vaccine availability and access.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Special Committee on Aging (US)
Title: Combating the Flu: Keeping Seniors Alive
Description: The Senate Special Committee on Aging held a hearing to examine federal, state, and local efforts to prevent deaths of senior citizens from influenza, focusing on influenza vaccine recommendations, improved vaccine coverage, and antiviral drugs. The Committee reviewed adjustments the public health system had made in response to a vaccine shortage along with an early flu season the previous year. The Committee concluded that in order to address challenges of the flu, it was necessary to speed up vaccine production, enhance monitoring to detect new viruses, and continue informational campaigns on the importance of routine flu vaccination.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Special Committee on Aging (US)
Title: Liability, Licensing and the Flu Vaccine Market: Making Decisions Today to Prevent a Crisis Tomorrow
Description: The Senate Special Committee on Aging held a hearing to examine liability and licensing issues relating to the influenza vaccine market. Discussion focused on the ongoing efforts of the Food and Drug Administration to ensure the safety, effectiveness, and availability of influenza and other vaccines licensed in the United States.

Committee(s) (modern name as of 2020): Senate Special Committee on Aging (US)
Title: Preparing for Pandemic Flu
Description: The Senate Special Committee on Aging held an oversight hearing on the Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) efforts to prepare for pandemic influenza. The committee heard from testimony the the HHS Secretary and experts outside of the federal government. Discussion centered on the particular vulnerability of older adults during an influenza pandemic, the value of public health messaging toward older adults' communities, and the importance of incorporating older adults' needs into all aspects of pandemic planning.
